- The target line color is inferred from the marker’s 4-neighborhood (up/down/left/right): the marker becomes the color of the line segment it is attached to (the adjacent non-0 line color).  
- If a marker touches multiple line colors, it likely chooses the one that forms a straight continuation through the marker (collinear neighbor pair) or the dominant/most-connected adjacent line.

2) Line completion by filling gaps (0 → line color)
- For each line color in **{1,3,6,7}**, broken line segments are “repaired”:
  - If two cells of the same line color are aligned in the same **row** or **column**, any intervening **0** cells (and sometimes marker cells **2/4**) between them can be filled with that same line color, producing a continuous straight segment.
  - This is seen both horizontally and vertically, and for gaps of size 1 or larger.

3) Overwriting to resolve crossings / intersections (line color A → line color B)
- Some cells already containing a different non-0 line color are recolored to another line color to enforce continuity of the “repaired” line.
- Effect: at an intersection, one line is allowed to “pass through” (occupies the shared cell) while the other becomes visually interrupted at that cell.
- A plausible condition seen across examples:
  - Overwriting at intersections is more likely when the intersection cell was already **non-0 in the original input** (i.e., it was an existing crossing/occupied point), rather than a brand-new drawn cell.
- Possible tie-break behaviors (all consistent with at least some examples):
  - The color that “needs” the cell to connect two same-colored endpoints on opposite sides (left/right or up/down) takes the intersection cell.
  - Or a fixed priority/order of drawing may exist (different examples suggest different local outcomes), causing the “later” repaired line to overwrite the earlier one at pre-existing intersections.

4) Special behavior tied to marker 4 (extension to border + pruning)
(Seen in examples containing **4**.)
- After converting **4** to its attached line color, the line is extended **beyond** that endpoint marker in the outward direction (away from the already-present adjacent segment) until it hits the grid boundary, painting intervening **0** cells with the same line color.
- This extension can also overwrite existing non-0 intersection cells (creating/using crossings) along the way.
- Additionally, some parts of that same line color may be **removed** (set to **0**) on the “opposite side” of the nearest junction/branching point, effectively keeping the branch that leads through the former **4** marker and discarding the other continuation.
- Disconnected fragments of that same line color (not connected to the kept branch) may also be erased to **0**.

5) Pruning / deletion of line fragments (line color → 0)
- Some existing line segments are removed entirely (set to **0**), especially:
  - segments that become “extra branches” after the marker-4 branch selection,
  - or components not connected to the main/selected structure after extensions and crossing resolution.
